Un peu du mal à comprendre toute cette vague de moutons qui ont installés le jeu sur Steam pour cracher dessus.
Overwatch "2" est trop proche du premier certes, mais il est complètement gratuit, pour 0 euro vous avez un jeu vraiment bon, et même si vous payez vous avez des choses intéressantes. 
10e tous les deux mois pour un pass, personnellement ça me dérange pas, j'aime le jeu.

Le passage en 5v5 a fait rager beaucoup, perso je préfère comme ça, je trouve le jeu plus dynamique.

Il y a toujours des bugs, des soucis d'équilibrage, mais globalement le jeu reste très bon, même si clairement Blizzard pourrait faire vraiment mieux. Il y a un sentiment de non fini sur OW2, c'est frustrant oui, mais le jeu reste bon, et je ne pense pas que cracher dessus résoudra tout.

Well, well, well, what do we have here? Overwatch 2, huh? Or as I like to call it, "Over-hyped 2: Electric Boogaloo." Strap in, folks, because we're about to dive into a whirlwind of disappointment and frustration that's somehow wrapped up in shiny new graphics.

Remember when we were promised groundbreaking graphics that would make our eyes pop out of our heads? Yeah, well, I'm still waiting for my eyes to even twitch. The so-called "upgrades" look like someone tried to slap a fresh coat of paint on a 10-year-old game and called it a day. I mean, come on, even my grandma's cat could tell you that this isn't what we signed up for.

And let's not even get started on the gameplay. Overwatch 2 feels like a game stuck in limbo between a mid-life crisis and a kindergarten playground. You'd think they would've figured out how to balance heroes by now, but nah, let's just let Genji keep bouncing around like he's on a sugar high. Oh, and guess what? They managed to introduce new heroes that are just as annoyingly unbalanced as the old ones. Bravo, Blizzard, bravo.

Now, let's talk about the PvE mode that was supposed to be the game's saving grace. Ever wanted to shoot at hordes of mindless robots that make your grandma's knitting circle look like an action movie? Well, you're in for a treat! The missions are about as exciting as watching paint dry, and the enemies are so brain-dead that I'm convinced they're actually just lost tourists looking for the nearest gift shop.

But wait, there's more! Remember those sweet, sweet cosmetic items you used to earn by being a halfway decent player? Yeah, say goodbye to that concept. Overwatch 2 has decided to embrace its inner capitalist and flood the game with more microtransactions than you can shake a loot box at. Want a new skin for your favorite hero? Just hand over your credit card and pray to the RNG gods.

In conclusion, Overwatch 2 is like that friend who promises to throw an epic party but ends up serving stale chips and lukewarm soda. It's a mishmash of broken promises, lackluster improvements, and a money-hungry attitude that would make even Scrooge McDuck blush. If you're looking for a good time, you're better off hosting your own party with the original Overwatch and a bag of Doritos. Save your excitement for something that actually delivers on its hype.

It was a great game when it first came out, but even then it had a huge flaw that introduced loot boxes. And as time went on, the game didn't get better, it got worse.
This was ow 1, but there is no difference compared to ow 2, only that the bad microtransaction was replaced by an even worse one and now you have to buy the heroes separately. I used to be able to get legendary skins easily, but now it takes about months of grinding.
Finally, a big round of applause to the artists who turned it into porn despite Blizzard trying to prevent it, without you overwatch would be a dead game long ago.

Overwatch 1 got killed because they wanted to deliver a grand story mode with skill trees and the like.
What we got was an empty, free to play Battle Pass model that only serves to make Blizzard money.

Every other season you have the choice of spending £9.99 to play the new content or spending 30+ hours levelling to unlock the character, most of the casual player intensives like cosmetic rewards are no longer available for f2p players unless you are happy with earning a voice line once every 3 months. Having spent £40 on the game in 2016 its a slap in the face to be compensated with two of the ugly cosmetics and a icon for a thanks for supporting their game for the past 6 years

The game being released on steam is just a trap to lure in more players into their dying game so they can try to get more people to pay them money.
Don't fall for it.
